Abstract 26
The need for an environmental risk assessment for engineered nanomaterials (ENM) necessitates the 27 knowledge about their environmental concentrations. Despite significant advances in analytical meth-28 ods, it is still not possible to measure the concentrations of ENM in natural systems. Material flow and 29 environmental fate models have been used to provide predicted environmental concentrations. How-30 ever, almost all current models are static and consider neither the rapid development of ENM produc-31 tion nor the fact that many ENM are entering an in-use stock and are released with a lag phase. Here 32 we use dynamic probabilistic material flow modelling to predict the flows of four ENM (nano-TiO2, 33 nano-ZnO, nano-Ag and CNT) to the environment and to quantify their amounts in (temporary) sinks 34 such as the in-use stock and (“final”) environmental sinks such as soil and sediment. Caused by the in-35 crease in production, the concentrations of all ENM in all compartments are increasing. Nano-TiO2 36 had far higher concentrations than the other three ENM. Sediment showed in our worst-case scenario 37 concentrations ranging from 6.7 µg/kg (CNT) to about 40’000 µg/kg (nano-TiO2). In most cases the 38 concentrations in waste incineration residues are at the “mg/kg” level. The flows to the environment 39 that we provide will constitute the most accurate and reliable input of masses for environmental fate 40 models which are using process-based descriptions of the fate and behaviour of ENM in natural sys-41 tems and rely on accurate mass input parameters. 42

Introduction 50
Concerns about the potential environmental risks induced by the exposure to engineered nanomaterials 51 (ENM) are growing. An environmental risk by ENM might occur when the exposure to these materials 52 exceeds an ecotoxicological limit concentration in environment.1 Therefore, knowing the current lev-53 els of ENM in environment is a fundamental step to assess the environmental risk of these materials. 54 To date, the quantification of ENM in environmental samples, especially in solid samples such as soil 55
and sediment, is still not possible. 2, 3 On the one hand, ENM are in most cases not directly detectable 56 by analytic methods due to their very low concentration; on the other hand, even if detected, there are 57 still major difficulties to differentiate the naturally occurring nanomaterials from the ENM. 4 In order to 58 perform a proactive environmental risk analysis, currently the only way to obtain information on exist-59
ing levels of ENM in the environment is to model predicted environmental concentrations (PEC). 2, 5 60 Several modelling studies have presented quantitative estimations of the environmental concentrations 61
of ENM 2, 6-12 . Mechanistic models specifically considering agglomeration and sedimentation reactions 62 of ENM have also been developed13, 14. 63
However, all the material flow models published so far are static and do not consider time-dependent 64 processes with respect to the use and release of ENM. The current models consider only the input by 65 production, manufacturing and consumption (PMC) into the system that occurs in one year and subse-66 quently distribute the mass over the entire system in the same year. The models also assume that all 67 ENM produced are released to waste streams and environmental compartments in the same year that 68 they enter the system and no in-use stocks are considered. With these two oversimplifications of the 69 true situation, the static models do not represent the actual ENM flows to environmental compartments 70 under conditions where a rapid increase in production of ENM is taking place15 and when they are en-71 tering in-use stocks. Moreover, the static models cannot predict concentrations in environmental sinks, 72 such as soil or sediment, because these compartments accumulate inputs over many years. 73
First attempts in considering accumulation in environmental sinks have been made by Gottschalk et 74 al.9 who used a very simplistic model to scale the input in different years to calculate final concentra-75 tions in soil and sediment. Sun et al. made a spatio-temporal prediction of mass-flows and concentra-76 tions for five ENM in biosolids amended soil in South Australia over a period between 2005 and 77
2012. 16 However, both studies only considered one aspect of the dynamic nature of the system, the pe-78 riodic production inputs into the system. The delayed ENM release from in-use stock was not covered 79 at all so far. 80
A more realistic prediction of ENM flows to the environment therefore requires a dynamic material-81 flow analysis model (MFA). Unlike the static models, the dynamic MFA takes a reasonable time frame 82 as the temporal system boundary and tracks the flows over many years; it also no longer needs the 83 simplified assumption that all ENM are immediately released from all applications when they are pro-84

ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
5
duced. Dynamic MFA is a well-established modelling technique. Müller et al. 17 performed a review 85 on dynamic material flow modelling methods and studied whether and how uncertainty is treated by 86 these methods. More than half of the methods covered by this review did not consider uncertainty at 87 all; while there are some that use sensitivity analysis (37%), Gaussian error propagation (6%) or pa-88 rameter ranges (5%), but none supports a full uncertainty representation with probability. The proba-89 bilistic dynamic MFA (DP-MFA) method developed by Bornhöft et al.18 fills this knowledge gap. This 90 model treats all the uncertainty with probabilistic approaches. It constitutes the fundamental platform 91 based on which the dynamic materials flow model of ENM is built. 92
The aim of this work was to build a customised dynamic probabilistic material flow model (DP-MFA) 93 based on the method recently developed by Bornhöft et al.18 This new model predicts the former, cur-94 rent and future mass-flows of four ENM - nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-Ag, and CNT - to technical and 95 environmental compartments and the resulting concentrations in these compartments over time. 96

Methods 97

sections.heading: General principle 98
sections.text:
The new DP-MFA model for the four ENM is distinguished from all previous static models by the fol-99 lowing two aspects: 1) time scope consideration of a period rather than a single year; 2) time depend-100 ent ENM release from products over the life-cycle of the products rather than simply assuming com-101 plete ENM release from products in one year when they are produced. We call the first point input 102 dynamics in the context of this study, and the latter release dynamics. The input dynamics describe the 103 annual production of ENM as inflows into the system within a given period. The release dynamics de-104 scribe the time-dependent ENM release kinetics from a specific product category over the entire life-105 cycle. 106
Following a life-cycle concept, the model tracks the ENM mass-flows from ENM production to incor-107 poration into the commercial products and finally from the products to technical and environmental 108
compartments during/after their use and disposal 19 . Probabilistic methods are employed for all the pa-109 rameters used in the modelling processes to address the inherent uncertainty in the raw data used20. 110 This means data from varied sources, with inherently different reliability, are combined into an appro-111 priate probability density distribution. The input data for the model are the annual production amounts 112 of ENM in the EU, the estimated shares of ENM applied onto product categories, the process-based 113 transfer coefficients within and among the technical systems and the transfer coefficients between en-114 vironmental compartments. All these parameters are treated as appropriate probability distributions 115 depending on the data available. For each of the parameters, 100’000 random iterations are made to 116 represent the comprehensive picture of the probability density distribution as described in a previous 117 study20. 118
The scheme of the DP-MFA is shown in Figure 1. It consists of two modules: the “Release Module” 119 and the “Distribution Module”. The “Release Module” addresses the input and release dynamics. It 120 describes the annual ENM production/consumption entering the system, the estimated share onto 121 product categories, the flows from product categories by immediate release or into in-use stocks and 122 finally the release from in-use stocks. The total annual release of ENM is then transferred to the com-123 partments of the “Distribution Module”. The “Distribution Module” is built upon the previous static 124 model11, which describes the ENM transfers within and between technical and environmental com-125
partments. The transfer coefficients for the “Distribution Module” summarised from Sun (2014) 11 are 126 listed in the supporting information Table S5. 127
128
System boundary 129
Page 6 of 27
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
7
The geographical focus of this study is the European Union (EU) due to the abundant information 130 available. But modelling for other regions can be easily expanded once data needed are provided. The 131 technical compartments included in this study are landfills, sewage treatment plants (STP), waste in-132 cineration plants (WIP), recycling and export. The environmental compartments considered are at-133 mosphere, natural and urban soil, sewage sludge treated soil, surface waters and sediment. Among the-134 se compartments, landfills, soil and sediment are defined as sink compartments. From sink 135 compartments no downstream flows are modelled. A study by Caballero et al.21 was included provid-136 ing an explicit description of ENM fate during and after recycling processes. 137
In this study we track the mass of the initial ENM. Transformed ENM (in our definition particles 138 which lose their nano features i.e. by incineration, dissolution, or chemical reactions) will be viewed 139 as loss of the ENM and flow to a virtual compartment called “Elimination”. 140
141 142 PC: Product Category; Technical systems: landfills, sewage treatment plants, waste incineration, recycling, and export; Envi-143 ronment: Air, soil (natural and urban soil and sewage sludge treated soil), surface water, sediment; Stock indicates the mass 144 stocked for both “Use release” and “EoL release” which are further explained in the following section “Release dynamics”. 145 146
Figure 1: Schematic of the probabilistic dynamic material flow model for ENM. It consists of two mod-147 ules, the “Release Module” and the “Distribution Module”. The “Release Module” focuses on dynamic 148 system behaviour, describing both the input dynamics and the release dynamics. The “Distribution 149 Module” describes ENM distributions within and between technical and environmental systems after 150 they are released out of the use phase. 151

Input dynamics 153

We considered in our model a time frame from 1990 to 2020. Explanations of the definition of the 154 time frame are given in the Supplementary Information (SI). The estimation of production of ENM 155 over time is made by multiplying the base year production (2012) with retrospective and prospective 156 scaling factors. The production of the four ENM in 2012 is based on the probability distributions pro-157
vided by Sun et al. 11 updated with newly available data. Table S1 shows the raw data used for building 158 the probability distribution of the ENM production in 2012. The scaling factors for each individual 159 year are based on ENM market projections, nanotechnology patent analysis, and direct information on 160 ENM production15. We use the assumption that the development of ENM production is proportional to 161 nanotechnology development with respects to e.g. patents registrations, funding etc. A summary of all 162 the data used for estimating probability distributions of the scaling factors are summarised in Table S2. 163 The probability distribution of ENM production in 2012 and the probability distributions of scaling 164 factors are multiplied to obtain the probability distribution of ENM production for the period from 165 1990 to 2020. Production data in 2012 are used as the reference because they are available in Sun et 166 al.11. 167
For nano-Ag, an additional estimation of the production development for a period from 1900 to 2020 168 has been made. This longer time period is founded in the historic applications of “silver colloids” that 169
are in fact nano-Ag. 22 Detailed information on how this was done can be found in the SI. 170
171
Release dynamics 172
“Release” in our definition refers to ENM that leave the production, manufacturing, and consumption 173 phase and are transferred to technical or environmental compartments. The total ENM production is 174 assigned to different nano-enabled product categories in shares based on the information provided by a 175
previous study. 11 This allocation of ENM to product categories is assumed to remain constant over the 176 time considered in this study. Figure 2 shows the scheme of how time dependent ENM release from 177 products is expressed in the model. It proceeds in four steps: allocation of total ENM to different 178 products❶, separation of ENM allocated to one product category into the “Use release” and “End of 179 Life (EoL) release” ❷, scheduling of “Use and EoL release” ❸, allocation of ENM to technical 180 and/or environmental compartment after “Use release” and “EoL release”❹. Scheduling in this con-181 text indicates the allocation of ENM mass released over the time. 182

183
TC: Transfer Coefficient; EoL: End of Life 184
Figure 2: Schematic visualization of the time dependent ENM release dynamics. For ENM contained in 185 a product category, the first step ❶ is the allocation of total produced ENM to different products. The 186 second step ❷ is the division of the total ENM-content between the “Use release” and “EoL release”. 187 The ENM contained in a product category allocated to “Use release” is the fraction supposed to be re-188 leased during its use phase; the part allocated to “EoL release” is the fraction supposed to be remain-189 ing in the product and be released once the products come to their end of life. The third step ❸ is the 190 definition of the duration of the “Use release” and the “EoL release” as well as the release schedule; in 191 other words in how many years the release events take place for one product category and how much 192 of the fraction is released each year. The “EoL release” depends on the life-time distributions of each 193 product category; here normal distributions are assumed. The fourth step ❹ is the allocation of the 194 released ENM from the scheduled “Use release” and “EoL release” to technical and environmental 195 compartments. 196
197
Table 1 depicts the dynamic release parameters for nano-Ag as an example. The respective data for the 198 other ENM are given in the SI. This table demonstrates the division of the release between “Use re-199 lease” and “EoL release”, the release schedule over time and the allocation to different compartments 200 after release. As Table 1 shows, important products categories such as “Electronics and Appliances”, 201 “Medtech” and “Paints” have the major part of nano-Ag remaining in the product and it is released 202 when it reaches the end of life. In contrast, product categories like “Textiles”, “Cosmetics”, “Foods”, 203 “Cleaning agents” and “Plastics” have their nano-Ag component released mainly during the use phase. 204
Product life times are often independent of the ENM application, therefore they are either well known 205 or can be easily estimated. The release kinetics of ENM is specific to which ENM is applied to and 206
Page 9 of 27
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
10
how the material is bound to a product. This information is based preferably on experimental data 207 when it is available or estimated on the basis of expert judgement. The use of realistic data compared 208
to worst-case assumptions 7-12, 23 ensures a realistic modelling effort. 209
The product categories “Electronics & Appliances”, “Plastics”, “Paints”, “Metals” and “Filters” have 210 life-times normally longer than 5 years. With 20 years of use release, “Metals” is the product category 211 with the longest use release. “Electronics and Appliances”, the most important product category for 212
nano-Ag, has an average life-time of 8 years. 24 Fast release is found in non-durable product categories 213 for instance “Cosmetics”, “Foods”, “Cleaning agents” and “Medtech”. For these, we have estimated 214 general use release durations of 1 to 2 years. Experimental studies indicated that the majority of nano-215 Ag release takes place in the early stage of their life-time.25, 26 Therefore, in the use release schedule 216 release is mostly allocated to the first year. Most nano-Ag released during use release end up in waste 217 water, which was evaluated on the basis of a previous study11. 218
In our approach, the EoL release schedule of ENM for a product category is represented by its life-219 time distribution, i.e. the time it takes until the products are discarded. The longest EoL release is es-220 timated for “Paints”. Although “Paints” have an average use release duration of 8 years, the EoL re-221 lease duration is in average 80 years, governed by the life-time of the buildings they are applied to.27, 28 222 Complete use release in the first year is assumed for product categories with fast use release, such as 223 “Foods”, “Cleaning agents” and “Medtech”. Distribution of nano-Ag to landfill, WIP, recycling and 224 export after EoL releases are made according to solids waste management statistics in the EU for gen-225 eral solid waste29 and specific waste30-35. 226
227
Calculation of concentrations 228
Concentrations are calculated by using standard volumes of environmental compartments (based on 229 the REACH guidance36). There are either flow-through compartments (e.g. water, air) without accu-230 mulation and sinks (e.g. soil, sediment) with accumulation. Additionally, for air and surface water, a 231 retention time of 10 (Anastasio and Martin, 200137) and 40 (ECB, 200336) days were used, therefore 232 10/365 and 40/365 of the yearly input flows into these compartments were considered as the fraction 233 of ENM remaining in the two compartments. The value for air is not particle specific but represents an 234 average residence time of particles smaller than 100 nm in air. Over the timescale of the modelling (1 235 year) in principle all particles settle out of the atmosphere. This value is therefore not a very critical 236 one in our model and using an average value is therefore reasonable. A summary of the volumes of the 237 compartments is given in supporting information Table S7. 238

Results and discussion 249
Mass-flows of the four ENM 250
Flows of the four ENM from production and use to release into all compartments were modelled by 251 combining the modelled production volumes, shares of ENM applied in products and transfer factors 252 between all the compartments for the year 2014, incorporating the dynamics of the system from 1990 253 to 2014, as shown in Figure 3. The mean total productions of nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, CNT and nano-254 Ag estimated for EU in 2014 were 39’000, 7’300, 730 and 50 tonnes respectively. Depending on the 255 products applying these materials, different shares of amounts currently produced are entering into in-256 use stock or are released into technical and environmental compartments. For nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO 257 and nano-Ag, about half of the year’s total input into the system enters the in-use stock and the rest is 258 directly released during the same year. With respect to CNT, less than 1% (1 out of 730 tons) is direct-259 ly released and nearly 100% is allocated to the in-use stock. The amount in the in-use stock up to 2014 260 for nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO and nano-Ag is in general around two times of their input in 2014; for CNT 261 it is four times because the majority is stocked. Releases from in-use stock together with the immedi-262 ate release from 2014’s input constitute the total release in 2014. Compared to the immediate release, 263 the release from stocks (previous year’s input into the system) is in most cases much smaller, being 264 about 15-30% of the total annual release. The one exception are CNT, for which more than 99% of the 265 annual release in 2014 is coming from in-use stock, again showing their particular applications in pol-266 ymer nano-composites which result in little immediate release. 267
This importance of releases from in-use stocks justifies the need for a dynamic modelling of ENM. 268 Because flows into a certain product category are split into stocked and released amounts, it is not pos-269 sible to compare the new results to those of static models such as from Sun (2014) or Keller (2014)10, 270 11, 23 . In these models the production in one year was completely distributed to the environment, an as-271 sumption that our dynamic modelling has clearly shown to be not representative for the ENM investi-272 gated. 273
The most prominent flows for nano-TiO2 and nano-ZnO after release were from production, manufac-274 turing, and consumption (PMC) to wastewater (and further to STP). This is due to the fact that the ma-275 jor applications for these two ENM are in cosmetics (the priority columns in Table 1 and Table S6 276 shows the shares for all ENM applications). For nano-Ag, the major flows are from PMC to landfill 277 and to waste water. The most prominent flows for CNT were from PMC to landfill, followed by the 278 flow to WIP, and from there to elimination. This can be explained by the fact that most of these mate-279 rials are applied in polymer composites. ENM flows through the STP are mainly captured in STP 280 sludge, and further transported to WIP and landfill, and some ENM end up in soil from sludge applica-281 tion. After wastewater treatment processes, nano-ZnO is transformed into different chemical forms 282
such as ZnS, Zn sorbed to iron oxides and Zn3(PO4) 40, 41 and thus allocated to the virtual elimination 283
Page 12 of 27
ACS Paragon Plus Environment
Environmental Science & Technology
13
compartment. As mentioned above, after passing through wastewater treatment, most of the metallic 284 nano-Ag is transformed to Ag sulphides and is therefore also ending up in the elimination compart-285 ment (and therefore left the system because the metallic nano-Ag property was lost). 286
With respect to recycling, we were able to include the fate of ENM during recycling based on a recent 287
modelling study of ENM flows during recycling 21 . We were therefore able to follow the majority of 288 the mass flowing to recycling on their way to subsequent compartments. 289
One of the reasons to conduct a dynamic modelling endeavour is to calculate the ENM loads in com-290 partments that accumulate ENM. With the dynamic model we are able to provide the accumulated 291 mass of ENM in landfills, soil and sediment, with the values shown in black squares in Figure 3. All 292 these three compartments are important sinks of ENM. In general, the accumulated masses are about 293 five times larger than the contemporary input flows in 2014. For nano-TiO2 sludge treated soil (with 294 45’000 tons) is found to be the largest accumulator, followed by sediment (with 43’000 tons) and land-295 fills (with 40’000 tons). For nano-ZnO, sediments accumulate the most (with 7’000 tons), followed by 296 natural and urban soil (with 1’400 tons) and landfill (1’000 tons). Nano-Ag finds its most significant 297 accumulations in landfills (40 tons) and sediment (30 tons). In the case of CNT, landfills dominate the 298 list with almost 500 tons, while the accumulated masses in other sinks are less than 30 tons. One reason to conduct a dynamic modelling endeavour is to describe the former and predict the future 330 development. Figure 4 shows the modelled mean and 15% and 85% quantiles concentrations evolution 331 of nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-Ag and CNT in the EU from 1990 to 2020 (for nano-Ag an additional 332 scenario from 1900 to 2020, provided in Figure S2). The compartments for which concentrations of 333 ENM are calculated are assumed to be well-mixed and homogenous, although natural and urban soil 334 and sewage sludge treated soil are differentiated. These concentrations are therefore representative for 335 an average hypothetical region as defined in the REACH guidance42. All details about the parameters 336 used to calculate the concentrations are given in Table S7. 337
Triggered by the increase in production, the concentrations of all ENM in all compartments are in-338 creasing. Some of the compartments are flow-through compartments with no accumulation such as 339 sludge, waste and wastewater effluents, others are accumulating sinks such as sediment and soil. Regarding the development, nano-TiO2, 342 nano-ZnO and nano-Ag follow a similar pattern. A dominant majority of the products applying CNT are 346 “durable” products, such as polymer composite that have almost no CNT release during use. Release 347 takes place only when they come to the disposal phase. This leads the fact that most of CNT end up in 348 solid waste over time, and further results in higher concentration there. Although in reality there may well be ENM in landfill leachates, our model did not take this into ac-405 count due to the insufficient quantitative information that exists on this process. It also needs to be 406 noted that the concentrations in surface water and sediment reflect worst-case scenarios for both com-407 partments. However, 409 our flow results can be used as input data for dedicated mechanistic fate models that all rely on accu-410 rate predictions of the input flows. 411
Due to the different dynamic and static modelling concepts applied, it is not really possible to draw a 412
direct comparison between the newly predicted concentrations results with all previous studies 8-11, 16, 23 . 413 As stated in the mass flow section above, the previous models distributed the produced mass in one 414 year to the whole system in that year while our dynamic modelling clearly revealed that in-use stocks 415 and delayed releases are highly important and essentially define the system behaviour. However, this 416 does not necessarily lead to lower predicted concentrations because releases from previous years are 417 also considered and in some cases may dominate the flows. Similar concentrations in 2014 predicted 418 by static and dynamic models may therefore by chance have the same magnitude. Extending the 419 simulation time will reveal larger and larger differences between the two approaches due to additional 420 releases from stocks. 421
The values presented in Table 2 include both the uncertainty in some of the parameters as well as the 422 variability that is caused by the representation of a range of different forms of an ENM (e.g. coatings, 423 functionalization), which are subsumed under the label of a generic ENM, e.g. nano-TiO2. In our ap-424 proach, single numbers are treated as distributions. Triangular, uniform, normal and other distributions 425 are used alone or combined in accordance to available data. This treatment of the available data allows 426 us to consider for each parameter the knowledge that is available by including always the specific un-427 certainty associated with each parameter. 428
The major purpose of the dynamic modelling is to track the historical concentrations and project the 429 future concentrations of ENM in accumulative compartments. Therefore, besides the ENM concentra-430 tions predicted for the year 2014, we also provide the concentrations in 2020 in Table S8. The concentrations we provide for the technical compartments, e.g. wastewater, sludge or bottom ash-439 es and the ENM loads into environmental compartments, e.g. surface water, soil and air (see Table S9), 440 can be used as input values for more sophisticated environmental fate models that incorporate a mech-441 anistic description of fate processes, e.g. agglomeration and sedimentation. These models then add an-442 other level of complexity with respect to dynamic modelling because they are considering the dynam-443 ics of physical and chemical reactions not included in our flow models. Praetorius et al. for example 444 used the ENM mass flow to natural waters from Gottschalk et al. 9 as input to their mechanistic river 445 fate modelling of nano-TiO2 13. Also Gottschalk et al.43 used the release from wastewater from the 446 same source as input for a local modelling study with high spatial resolution of ENM within the Swiss 447 river network. In another example using the same dataset, Dumont et al.44 calculated the spatial distri-448
bution of ENM in European watersheds. Meesters et al. 45 took the emission data to air, water and soil 449 from the Mueller (2008)8 mass-flow model as their SimpleBox4Nano model input. Liu et al.46 used the 450
ENM emission results from Gottschalk et al. 9 and Keller et al. 23 as input data for their fate model. Dale 451 et al.47 used the US emission data for nano-Ag and nano-ZnO from Gottschalk et al.9 and included a 452 modelling of the dynamics of water and sediment flows in streams and chemical transformations. This 453 list exemplifies that the data provided by mass flow models are absolutely crucial for the fate models 454 to come up with correct environmental concentrations as they all rely on mass inputs into one or sev-455 eral environmental compartments. The results of our dynamic model provide so far the most reliable 456 and accurate results by incorporating ENM accumulation and release and they constitute the funda-457 mental input information for predicting realistic concentrations results by environmental fate models. 458 The use of dynamic MFA models is standard in assessing flows of materials in situations with rapid 459 technological changes 17 and our new dynamic MFA modelling of ENM is making use of this tool. 460 Whereas the dynamic modelling requires more input data, we have shown that it is feasible to estimate 461 the required data by combining information on technology development, release and fate processes in 462 technical systems. In a situation with rapid increase in production and use of ENM, the modelling of 463 environmental sinks needs to include historic uses that were much smaller (and future ones that might 464 be much higher). The use of ENM in products with a long delay before any substantial release may 465 occur (as is the case for ENM contained in polymers), is another strong argument for the use of a dy-466 namic model that is able to capture the stocks of ENM contained in products. 467
We have to stress here that the concentrations reported in our work for environmental sinks such as 468 soils and sediments do not consider any further chemical reaction such as dissolution or transfor-469 mation, which will likely be very important for materials such as Ag and ZnO. To include these reac-470 tions into models will require the use of the above-mentioned environmental fate models. The results 471 we provide are therefore worst-case assumptions on accumulated concentrations. Furthermore, be-472 cause our model tracks the ENM release with a one year-based resolution, the release variability be-473 tween seasons is not reflected in our study, e.g. consumption of sunscreen only takes place massively 474

The concentrations in natural compartments that we calculated nevertheless provide ecotoxicologists 477 and risk assessors with crucial exposure data needed for first ecological risk assessments. As long as 478 analytical chemists are not able to quantify ENM at the natural concentrations and distinguish them 479 from the natural background particles, the modelled concentrations constitute the only source of envi-480 ronmental exposure information that we have available. The modelled concentrations have previously 481 been used to compare the exposure levels used in toxicological studies48 or to perform a full environ-482 mental risk assessment based on the comparison of PEC values with NOEC values (no observed effect 483 concentrations) extracted from the ecotoxicological literature1. These assessments rely on the provi-484 sion of accurate environmental exposure data and our dynamic modelling is able to provide the most 485 realistic and accurate numbers on flows and accumulated amounts in sinks. In the current situation a 486 validation of modeled data for environmental ENM exposure is not possible as discussed in Nowack et 487 al. (2015)4 but using the resulting data together in a mutually supportive way will advance the field of 488 ENM risk assessment. 489
